question:
It is estimated that 50% of emails are spam emails. Some software has been applied to filter these spam emails before they reach your inbox. A certain brand of software claims that it can detect 99% of spam emails, and the probability for a false positive is 5%. 

 Now if an email is detected as spam, then what is the probability that it is in fact a non-spam email?

answers.feedback: Correct: $\frac{P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Not Spam})P(\text{Not Spam})}{P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Spam})P(\text{Spam}) + P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Not Spam})P(\text{Not Spam})} \approx 0.048 $
False: $\frac{P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Not Spam})P(\text{Not Spam})}{P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Spam})P(\text{Spam}) + P(\text{Detected as spam}|\text{Not Spam})P(\text{Not Spam})}
